description: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
descriptionMD: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
name: Microsoft SQL Server 2016: Querying Data with Transact-SQL - 70-761
subtitle: Microsoft SQL Server 2016

episodes.description: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.386
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.386 --> 00:00:07.822
[SOUND] Hello, thank you for
choosing ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.822 --> 00:00:13.240
We're talking about Querying Data
with Transact-SQL, with Don Pezet.

4
00:00:13.240 --> 00:00:15.580
Don, tell us about Transact-SQL.

5
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:16.830
So Transact-SQL,

6
00:00:16.830 --> 00:00:20.810
it's actually an abbreviation for
Transact Structured Query Language.

7
00:00:20.810 --> 00:00:23.400
It is a language that we
use to talk to databases.

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.940
So if you have a relational database,

9
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:27.480
there's a ton of great
information in there.

10
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.190
You have to be able to get it out.

11
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:32.330
And one of the most common ways
to do that is through SQL, or

12
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:33.890
the Structured Query Language.

13
00:00:33.890 --> 00:00:38.740
Well, Transact-SQL is Microsoft's
implementation of SQL.

14
00:00:38.740 --> 00:00:40.750
And it's what they use on
their server products.

15
00:00:40.750 --> 00:00:45.662
So if you're using Microsoft SQL Server,
well, really, all the way back, or a long

16
00:00:45.662 --> 00:00:48.190
time, since their earliest versions of SQL
Server, but all the way to the newer ones

17
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:50.935
like 2016, which is what we're
gonna be using here in this show.

18
00:00:50.935 --> 00:00:55.580
Transact-SQL is how you're going to
talk to that server, so in this series,

19
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:57.360
that's one of the things that
we're going to learn is,

20
00:00:57.360 --> 00:01:01.110
if I've got a Microsoft SQL Server 2016,
How do I talk to it?

21
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.760
Now the cool part is that most
of this is standards based, so

22
00:01:04.760 --> 00:01:10.630
what you learn in this series can apply
to SQL 2014, SQL 2012, SQL 2000, SQL 6.

23
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:12.470
I mean, it just goes way, way back.

24
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:16.290
These languages, they haven't changed
all that much in all these years.

25
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:19.337
Now, the way the databases optimized
their performance, the way they work.

26
00:01:19.337 --> 00:01:22.415
The volumes of data that they can handle,
have gotten much larger and

27
00:01:22.415 --> 00:01:23.840
evolved quite a bit.

28
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:26.040
But by having a standard language,

29
00:01:26.040 --> 00:01:28.020
it gives us the ability
to do something awesome.

30
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:32.130
Which is to learn how to talk to the
database service in a consistent manner.

31
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:34.210
And that's what this course is all about.

32
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:36.037
>> You already got me excited
about the whole thing, but

33
00:01:36.037 --> 00:01:37.850
who is this show targeted towards?

34
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:39.010
>> All right, well,

35
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:44.110
it's really targeted to anybody who
needs to get data out of the database.

36
00:01:44.110 --> 00:01:46.218
Now, I could kinda trim
that down a little bit,

37
00:01:46.218 --> 00:01:48.410
like if you don't really
care about database.

38
00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:52.213
You just want the data, there's plenty of
third party graphic utilities you can use.

39
00:01:52.213 --> 00:01:55.395
There's things like Microsoft Access
that gives you a little Wizard that

40
00:01:55.395 --> 00:01:58.250
you can walk through, but
if you're trying to go to scale.

41
00:01:58.250 --> 00:02:01.390
If you're trying to be able to handle
any kind of high volume transactions.

42
00:02:01.390 --> 00:02:05.510
Those hand holding type programs,
they don't work.

43
00:02:05.510 --> 00:02:08.990
We actually have to get in and
talk to the database server.

44
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.410
Be able to get that information and
put information in, and

45
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:13.960
that's where SQL comes in.

46
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:17.550
So if your job responsibility involves
that, this is what you want to learn.

47
00:02:17.550 --> 00:02:20.170
Now what types of jobs would do that,
developers.

48
00:02:20.170 --> 00:02:23.740
Developers often times have to store data
for their applications in a database.

49
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.230
And be able to get the data back out for

50
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:28.570
their application uses,
so they need to know SQL.

51
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:33.410
We also have DevOps, people that
are standing up their own database server,

52
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:34.070
right?

53
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:36.000
They still need to be able to talk to it.

54
00:02:36.000 --> 00:02:37.710
We also have system administrators.

55
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:39.857
If you're a system administrator and
you're responsible for

56
00:02:39.857 --> 00:02:40.755
standing up a SQL Server.

57
00:02:40.755 --> 00:02:43.103
Well, some people just have
to install the server and

58
00:02:43.103 --> 00:02:45.910
then they turn it over to the dev team and
that's it.

59
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:48.730
But more often than not,
we're gonna need to be able to monitor and

60
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:49.870
maintain that database.

61
00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:52.720
And the way we do that is
by querying against it.

62
00:02:52.720 --> 00:02:54.470
Sending it commands,
seeing how it responds,

63
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:56.220
that's how we know it's up and active.

64
00:02:56.220 --> 00:02:58.270
Just because the server's powered
on doesn't mean it's working.

65
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:01.900
We need to know,
can I actually get data out of it?

66
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:06.080
So if you fall into any of those roles,
developer, DevOps, system administrator.

67
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:09.930
Or just somebody who wants to learn
more about the way the databases work.

68
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.612
Learning SQL is a great way to find
out how to talk to talk to it.

69
00:03:13.612 --> 00:03:15.103
And learning Transact-SQL,

70
00:03:15.103 --> 00:03:18.185
is a great way to learn how to
talk to Microsoft's SQL Servers.

71
00:03:18.185 --> 00:03:21.070
>> Wow, that sounds fantastic, is there
a certification available for the show?

72
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:25.260
>> Absolutely this is actually
the first step in becoming like

73
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:27.100
a Microsoft Certified SQL Engineer.

74
00:03:27.100 --> 00:03:30.360
So the first certification that we
start with is called the MCSA, and

75
00:03:30.360 --> 00:03:32.470
I've got Microsoft's page pulled up here.

76
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.930
The MCSA for SQL Server 2016,
if you look at it.

77
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:39.630
The very first course in that journey
is right here, course number one.

78
00:03:39.630 --> 00:03:44.860
It's exam 70-761, and
that's what our show is being based on.

79
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:48.120
So, in this show we're going to cover
each of the topics that are a part of

80
00:03:48.120 --> 00:03:49.150
that exam.

81
00:03:49.150 --> 00:03:52.080
So that we can learn what we
need to know to go and pass it.

82
00:03:52.080 --> 00:03:54.986
Now, by itself, that's not enough, but

83
00:03:54.986 --> 00:03:59.763
if you complete the next course or
next exam, the 70-762 exam.

84
00:03:59.763 --> 00:04:05.620
When you pas both of those,
you get your MCSA in SQL Server 2016.

85
00:04:05.620 --> 00:04:08.860
And from there you can even move on and
there's an MCSE that you can get.

86
00:04:08.860 --> 00:04:10.810
And there's several specializations for

87
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:13.290
big data and cloud databases,
and all of that.

88
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:17.764
But they all start right here
with this one, with this show,

89
00:04:17.764 --> 00:04:21.560
70-761, which is for SQL Server 2016.

90
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:24.510
Be aware that there are other ones for
the previous versions,

91
00:04:24.510 --> 00:04:26.445
like SQL Server 2012 and 2014.

92
00:04:26.445 --> 00:04:31.021
They shared a different exam, 70-741,
if that's the one you're looking for.

93
00:04:31.021 --> 00:04:32.675
Well, we have a whole
separate show film for

94
00:04:32.675 --> 00:04:34.650
that because there's
a different user interface.

95
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:38.130
Things look different, so
we filmed it specifically for that.

96
00:04:38.130 --> 00:04:39.830
Here though, things look different enough,

97
00:04:39.830 --> 00:04:42.590
that we actually got the dedicated
course specifically for it.

98
00:04:42.590 --> 00:04:44.471
And that's exactly what
we're gonna be learning.

99
00:04:44.471 --> 00:04:48.130
>> A good IT pro is always learning, and
what topics are covered in this show?

100
00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:51.450
Alright, well, it really all starts kinda,
from a beginner's perspective.

101
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:55.840
So what is Transact-SQL, what does it
look like, how do I type in the commands?

102
00:04:55.840 --> 00:04:58.280
And then,
once I know how to input commands,

103
00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:01.190
what are the commands to even use?

104
00:05:01.190 --> 00:05:04.043
And if we drill into that exam,
let me pull it up here.

105
00:05:04.043 --> 00:05:06.104
So I'm going to pull up
that 70-761 exam and

106
00:05:06.104 --> 00:05:08.590
I'll pull up the details
here from Microsoft.

107
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:10.740
They basically divide
things into three areas,

108
00:05:10.740 --> 00:05:13.640
now in the show we divided
it up into a lot more areas.

109
00:05:13.640 --> 00:05:16.460
Because this is, it's a lot to take
in just in three chunks, right?

110
00:05:16.460 --> 00:05:19.900
So I think we actually divide it into,
I can't remember, like 10 or

111
00:05:19.900 --> 00:05:21.080
11 different areas.

112
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:22.030
But when you look inside,

113
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:24.340
first off we start with Managing
data with Transact-SQL.

114
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:26.850
Notice that that's almost half the exam.

115
00:05:26.850 --> 00:05:30.210
A large part of the exam is based,
just on managing that data.

116
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:32.320
Actually interacting
with the database server,

117
00:05:32.320 --> 00:05:34.790
what Transact SQL is all about, right?

118
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:38.120
And if you break that apart you'll see
it's things like using SELECT queries.

119
00:05:38.120 --> 00:05:40.414
Which are the most
common types of queries,

120
00:05:40.414 --> 00:05:43.339
that's how we request
information from the database.

121
00:05:43.339 --> 00:05:46.108
How we combine data between
tables using joins,

122
00:05:46.108 --> 00:05:48.610
how we aggregate data using functions.

123
00:05:48.610 --> 00:05:51.460
That's all interacting with the database.

124
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:55.900
Then we get into doing advanced queries,
these are queries that not everybody uses.

125
00:05:55.900 --> 00:05:59.080
The ones up here in the first section,
everybody uses these.

126
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:01.710
You use these everyday,
just going to a website,

127
00:06:01.710 --> 00:06:03.885
coming to our website and
clicking on the course library.

128
00:06:03.885 --> 00:06:05.370
You're running these queries
in the background and

129
00:06:05.370 --> 00:06:06.210
you don't even know it, right?

130
00:06:06.210 --> 00:06:10.060
These happen everyday, the advance
queries aren't in every day things.

131
00:06:10.060 --> 00:06:11.820
These are more like an edge case or

132
00:06:11.820 --> 00:06:15.660
a corner case, where you can actually
get some great benefits by using these.

133
00:06:15.660 --> 00:06:18.510
Doing things like grouping sets,
and pivots, and unpivots.

134
00:06:18.510 --> 00:06:22.168
So you can change the data that you're
getting back from the database servers.

135
00:06:22.168 --> 00:06:24.820
So we'll get a chance to see that, that
makes up a smaller portion of the exam.

136
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:28.070
And then the smallest portion
is right down here at the end,

137
00:06:28.070 --> 00:06:31.350
programming databases
by using Transact SQL.

138
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:34.590
If you're given access to a SQL Server,
it has nothing on it.

139
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:38.900
It doesn't have a database, has no tables,
how do you get that set up?

140
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:41.410
So we focus on the infrastructure side,
how do I create the database?

141
00:06:41.410 --> 00:06:44.280
How do I create the tables,
how do I deal with data types.

142
00:06:44.280 --> 00:06:47.150
And actually work with that information,
inside of those tables?

143
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:51.350
Until we run through that process of being
able to maintain the integrity of our data

144
00:06:51.350 --> 00:06:52.340
on the server.

145
00:06:52.340 --> 00:06:55.190
It's a great way to see some of
the neat tools that are a part

146
00:06:55.190 --> 00:06:56.220
of Microsoft SQL Server.

147
00:06:56.220 --> 00:06:58.875
That set it apart from other
competitors that are out there.

148
00:06:58.875 --> 00:07:00.749
So that's kind of a rundown of it,

149
00:07:00.749 --> 00:07:04.703
now do be aware that this last section
here where programing databases.

150
00:07:04.703 --> 00:07:07.830
It's not as super-crazy in depth,
that if you're not a developer,

151
00:07:07.830 --> 00:07:08.890
don't worry, right?

152
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:11.230
It's something that everybody can tackle.

153
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:15.073
There's actually another course,
if we look down the little list here.

154
00:07:15.073 --> 00:07:18.130
You'll see this,
Provisioning SQL Databases.

155
00:07:18.130 --> 00:07:22.730
And that goes far more in-depth,
into all the different case scenarios for

156
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:23.670
deploying a database.

157
00:07:23.670 --> 00:07:26.570
Like doing it in the cloud or
locally or with replication, and

158
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:28.300
all these other crazy solutions.

159
00:07:28.300 --> 00:07:30.970
And there is another course
that's out there, this one.

160
00:07:30.970 --> 00:07:34.970
Developing SQL Data Models, and
Implementing a SQL Data Warehouse.

161
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:40.474
Those two as well go far more in-depth,
in how to get things set up.

162
00:07:40.474 --> 00:07:43.400
So here in 70-761 we're really
focusing on the bare minimum.

163
00:07:43.400 --> 00:07:45.724
What's the minimum it takes to
get a database up and running?

164
00:07:45.724 --> 00:07:48.830
And to get a table in place and
to be able to share some data with it?

165
00:07:48.830 --> 00:07:51.200
But those are the topics that we're
gonna be covering as we move the course.

166
00:07:51.200 --> 00:07:54.610
So by the time we're done, you'll be
able to complete each of these tasks.

167
00:07:54.610 --> 00:07:57.593
>> Fantastic, well, if this sounds like
something you'd be interested in, and

168
00:07:57.593 --> 00:07:58.134
it should be.

169
00:07:58.134 --> 00:08:01.750
Then Querying Data with
Transact-SQL is for you.

170
00:08:01.750 --> 00:08:05.502
So make sure you catch every single
episode, and thanks for watching ITProTV.

171
00:08:05.502 --> 00:08:10.513
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don provides the viewers with background on Transact-SQL and the differences between it and the ANSI standard Structured Query Language (SQL). He also introduces the three categories of T-SQL statements that will be explored throughout the remainder of the series.
episodes.title: Introduction to Transact-SQL

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use the Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) to issue T-SQL queries against a server. He shows how to install the SSMS and get it connected to a database. He also highlights some of the benefits of using the SSMS like IntelliSense syntax highlighting and autocomplete.
episodes.title: Introduction to Transact-SQL Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the SELECT statement. He demonstrates how to retrieve data from a SQL database using SELECT, and then shows how to use the WHERE clause to refine the results
episodes.title: Retrieving Data with SELECT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues demonstrating how to use the SELECT statement to retrieve data from a SQL server. He expands upon part 1 by demonstrating how to use ORDER BY, UNION and DISTINCT to further refine the results of a SELECT query.
episodes.title: Retrieving Data with SELECT Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to combine results from more than one table by using the JOIN clause. He demonstrates the basic operation of JOIN and then explains some methods to help simplify the SELECT query and make it more manageable.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues explaining how the JOIN clause can be used to generate results from multiple tables. He builds on part 1 by discussing other types of JOIN clauses that can be performed. He explains and demonstrates how to use INNER JOIN and three different types of OUTER JOIN.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up discussing how to use the JOIN clause to combine results from multiple tables. He builds on part 1 and part 2 by explaining how multiple JOIN clauses can be nested together and that you can even perform a JOIN between a table and itself.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to add data to a table in SQL by using the INSERT statement. He demonstrates adding a single record, and explains a few methods for adding multiple records at the same time.
episodes.title: Adding Data with INSERT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to modify data in a SQL database table by using the UPDATE statement. He demonstrates modifying a single record, and explains a few methods for modifying multiple records at the same time. He ends the show by explaining a common mistake that can lead to data loss.
episodes.title: Changing Data with UPDATE

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to remove data from a SQL database table by using the DELETE statement. First, he demonstrates deleting a single value by using the UPDATE statement. Next, he demonstrates deleting a single record, and explains a few methods for deleting multiple records at the same time. He ends the show by explaining a common mistake that can lead to data loss.
episodes.title: Removing Data with DELETE

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the OUTPUT clause. He demonstrates how to use the OUTPUT clause to get better result feedback from SQL server, and he also demonstrates how the OUTPUT clause can be used for backup and auditing purposes.
episodes.title: Recording Changes with OUTPUT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to SQL functions. He begins by demonstrating some simple functions and explains how to use more advanced functions that require input parameters.
episodes.title: Querying Data with Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues exploring functions in Transact-SQL. He explains some of the variations found between functions. Examples include scalar vs table-valued functions as well as deterministic vs non-deterministic functions
episodes.title: Querying Data with Functions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to combine multiple results together in order to meet the needs of your organization. He shows how to use the GROUP BY and HAVING clauses to aggregate results into a smaller data set.
episodes.title: Aggregating Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues working with functions in Transact-SQL. This time, he focuses on performing arithmetic by making use of the numerous matehmatical functions included with T-SQL.
episodes.title: Performing Arithmetic

episodes.description: In this episode, Don examins how Transact-SQL handles dates. He demontrates multiple ways to retrieve the current date and time from a SQL server. He then demonstrates a series of functions that can be used to modify the date to support your queries.
episodes.title: Working with Dates

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up the series on functions by examining some of the system functions built into Microsoft SQL server. He explains how user and session data can be retrieved and then demonstrates how to combine that data with the OUTPUT clause to create a better logging and auditing solution.
episodes.title: System Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to SQL data types. He explains what data types do and then walks the viewers through several of the default data types found in Microsoft SQL Server. He ends the show by demonstrating how data types can support and interfere with your queries.
episodes.title: Data Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues discussing SQL data types. He demonstrates how data types can effect your queries. At the end of the show, he discusses the IDENTITY special modifier that can significantly impact how data types are applied.
episodes.title: Data Types Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses how you can create custom data types to meet the needs of your organization. He explains how programatic data types can be developed with the Microsoft .NET Framework and he also shows how custom data types can be easily deployed via aliases in Transact-SQL.
episodes.title: Custom Data Types

episodes.description: a
episodes.title: Converting Data Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the challenges of working with multiple data types. He then demonstrates how to use CAST and CONVERT to alter the data type of query results to meet our needs.
episodes.title: Converting Data Types Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how NULL values can impact our queries. He then demonstrates using CASE, ISNULL and COALESCE to ensure we get the results we need.
episodes.title: Conditions and Nulls

episodes.description: In this episode, Don revisits the topic of functions. This time around, he demonstrates how to create custom functions that can directly support your business need. He wraps up by demonstrating how to create and use scalar and table-valued functions.
episodes.title: User Defined Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains what a stored function is in Microsoft SQL. He demonstrates several built-in stored procedures and then shows how to create and execute custom stored procedures to support your business needs.
episodes.title: Stored Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how SQL Views function. He walks the viewers through several scenarios where views can be very useful and then demonstrates how to create and use views in Transact-SQL.
episodes.title: Creating Views

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to transactions. He explains how transactions function and demonstrates how they can protect your data in the event of a failed query. He wraps up the episode with an example of how transactions can be used for troubleshooting and auditing.
episodes.title: Transactions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to transactions. He explains how transactions function and demonstrates how they can protect your data in the event of a failed query. He wraps up the episode with an example of how transactions can be used for troubleshooting and auditing.
episodes.title: Transactions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the importance of catching and reporting errors in your SQL scripts. He demonstrates how to use TRY/CATCH blocks, RAISERROR and THROW to collect and report error information. He ends the episode by updating an existing query to provide proper error handling.
episodes.title: Error Handling

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the importance of catching and reporting errors in your SQL scripts. He demonstrates how to use TRY/CATCH blocks, RAISERROR and THROW to collect and report error information. He ends the episode by updating an existing query to provide proper error handling.
episodes.title: Error Handling Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use subqueries to make complex queries more efficient. He explains how query execution plans are calculated and then shows how to measure whether or not a subquery can provide a performance improvement over a complex query.
episodes.title: Subqueries

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use subqueries to make complex queries more efficient. He explains how query execution plans are calculated and then shows how to measure whether or not a subquery can provide a performance improvement over a complex query.
episodes.title: Subqueries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don expands on methods by which we can group query results in Transact-SQL. He begins by demonstrating the limitations of the GROUP BY command. He then shows to we can use GROUPING SETS, CUBE and ROLLUP to provide more advanced aggregation of our results.
episodes.title: Grouping Sets and Cubes

episodes.description: In this episode, Don expands on methods by which we can group query results in Transact-SQL. He begins by demonstrating the limitations of the GROUP BY command. He then shows to we can use GROUPING SETS, CUBE and ROLLUP to provide more advanced aggregation of our results.
episodes.title: Grouping Sets and Cubes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to four methods to rank results in Transact-SQL. He explains the different scenarios where ranking data is useful and then demonstrates using RANK, DENSE_RANK, NTILE and ROW_NUMBER to provide ranking data in our desired form.
episodes.title: Ranking Data with Window Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to four methods to rank results in Transact-SQL. He explains the different scenarios where ranking data is useful and then demonstrates using RANK, DENSE_RANK, NTILE and ROW_NUMBER to provide ranking data in our desired form.
episodes.title: Ranking Data with Window Functions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don highlights a common problem with SQL tables where data is arranged in a form that is not useful for our needs. He then demonstrates how we can alter the arrangement of table data in RAM using the PIVOT and UNPIVOT commands to achieve our desired results.
episodes.title: Pivot and Unpivot Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how we can use functions to create on-demand views of existing table data. He then highlights a common error when using functions that return a table in our queries. Finally, he demonstrates how to use APPLY to overcome that error so that we can properly leverage our custom functions.
episodes.title: Table Expressions and Apply

episodes.description: n this episode, Don explains how we can work with XML data inside of Transact-SQL. He demonstrates how to configure the output of a query to be formatted as XML. He then demonstrates how to use XML data as the input for a query.
episodes.title: Working with XML

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how we can work with JSON data inside of Transact-SQL. He demonstrates how to configure the output of a query to be formatted as JSON. He then demonstrates how to use JSON data as the input for a query.
episodes.title: Working with JSON
